Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient with symptoms of the common cold has come in for a routine check-up.
Story: I glance at my phone between patient charts and see a message from Alex: “Can we talk? Had a rough day.” My heart sinks. I know he’s been waiting for feedback on his project, and from the tone, it’s not good news. I want to be there for him, to listen and reassure him, to be the girlfriend he needs right now. But as I step into the exam room, my patient is already seated, sniffling and coughing. I put on my professional smile, ask about symptoms, and start my examination. My mind keeps drifting to Alex—how he must be feeling, alone and disappointed. I feel the weight of my white coat, the responsibility to focus, to catch any sign that this is more than a cold. But my heart aches with the urge to comfort Alex, to send a quick message, to be present for him. The expectations pull at me from both sides, and I feel stretched thin, torn between the person I love and the duty I owe my patient.
